ratioCategories.description: Measures the company's ability to meet short-term obligations using the data from NLTS-PR FS 12 31 2024 Rev156-1 [1], [2].

ratios.name: Current Ratio
ratios.interpretation: At 2.01, the company meets the standard benchmark of 2:1, indicating sufficient assets to cover short-term liabilities [2].

ratios.name: Quick Ratio
ratios.interpretation: The ratio of 0.63 relies heavily on inventory. Excluding inventory, the company may struggle to pay immediate debts without liquidation [2].

ratios.name: Cash Ratio
ratios.interpretation: Cash reserves ($155,134) cover only 16% of current liabilities ($978,114), indicating a reliance on receivables and inventory turnover [1].

ratios.name: Working Capital
ratios.interpretation: Positive working capital of nearly $1M suggests operational stability, though much is tied up in Inventory ($1.34M) [1].

ratioCategories.description: Evaluates the company's ability to generate earnings relative to revenue and equity using data from [3] and [4].

ratios.name: Gross Profit Margin
ratios.interpretation: A margin of 22.73% is slightly below the target for equipment dealers (typically 25%+), potentially due to the high Cost of Goods Sold ($3.5M) [3].

ratios.name: Operating Profit Margin
ratios.interpretation: Strong operating efficiency; expenses are well managed relative to gross profit [3].

ratios.name: Net Profit Margin
ratios.interpretation: Net margin is robust at 9.32% ($423,154), indicating strong bottom-line performance despite tax provisions [3].

ratios.name: Return on Assets (ROA)
ratios.interpretation: High efficiency in using assets to generate profit. Note: Internal schedules calculated this higher (40%) using Pre-Tax Income [5].

ratios.name: Return on Equity (ROE)
ratios.interpretation: Exceptionally high return for shareholders, driven by the relatively low equity base ($532k) compared to Net Income [6].

ratios.name: EBITDA Margin
ratios.interpretation: Healthy earnings before interest, taxes, depreciation, and amortization ($789,577) [4].

ratioCategories.description: Assesses financial leverage and long-term solvency using data from [2] and [7].

ratios.name: Debt-to-Equity Ratio
ratios.interpretation: The company is highly leveraged (2.70), relying significantly more on debt ($1.4M) than equity ($532k) to finance operations [2].

ratios.name: Debt-to-Assets Ratio
ratios.interpretation: 73% of the company's assets are financed through debt, indicating higher financial risk.

ratios.name: Interest Coverage Ratio
ratios.interpretation: Excellent coverage; the company generates nearly 12x the earnings needed to cover its interest payments ($66,186) [7].

ratios.name: Equity Multiplier
ratios.interpretation: Indicates that for every dollar of equity, the company controls $3.70 in assets, confirming high leverage.

ratioCategories.description: Measures how effectively the company uses its assets using data from [8] and [9].

ratios.name: Asset Turnover
ratios.interpretation: The company efficiently generates $2.30 in revenue for every dollar of assets [5].

ratios.name: Inventory Turnover
ratios.interpretation: Turnover is low (2.61x), suggesting inventory sits for ~140 days. High inventory levels ($1.34M) may be tying up working capital [8].

ratios.name: Days Sales Outstanding
ratios.interpretation: Collection period is efficient at ~37 days, better than the standard 45-day commercial term [8].

ratios.name: Days Payable Outstanding
ratios.interpretation: The company takes ~49 days to pay vendors, which effectively finances operations but could strain supplier relationships [9].

ratios.name: Accounts Receivable Turnover
ratios.interpretation: Receivables are turned over nearly 10 times a year, indicating strong collection policies [8].

ratioCategories.description: Proxies used based on Net Income + Depreciation as Operating Cash Flow (OCF) due to truncation in source file [10]. Proxy OCF = $498,727.

ratios.name: Operating Cash Flow Ratio
ratios.interpretation: The company generates $0.51 in cash for every dollar of current liabilities, suggesting adequate liquidity.

ratios.name: Free Cash Flow (Proxy)
ratios.interpretation: Positive estimated free cash flow indicates funds available for debt reduction or reinvestment (CapEx assumed minimal/financed based on source text).

ratios.name: Cash Flow to Debt Ratio
ratios.interpretation: The company generates sufficient cash to pay off 35% of its total debt in a single year, a healthy solvency indicator.

overallAnalysis: Based on the Rev156-1 financials [1], NLTS-PR demonstrates strong profitability (ROE 79.5%) and efficient asset turnover (2.30x). However, the analysis reveals a distinct dichotomy between strong income generation and constrained liquidity. The Current Ratio (2.01) is healthy, but the Quick Ratio (0.63) and Cash Ratio (0.16) are low, exposing a heavy reliance on Inventory ($1.34M) which turns over slowly (140 days). The company is highly leveraged (Debt/Equity 2.70), likely utilizing floorplan financing [11] to support this inventory. While Interest Coverage (11.93) is excellent, optimizing inventory levels could significantly improve liquidity and reduce working capital strain.
